explanation:
Symbols required and why:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of the target function. Any for-loops in this function (or side effects from called subfunctions) become part of the target function’s effective loop body and must be inspected for MISRA well-formedness and forbidden side effects.

- OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl: Direct callee executed when OS_ObjectIdGetById succeeds. Its implementation must be inspected for for-loops and side effects on objects that could interact with loop clauses in the call chain.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById. Included because its control flow or loops contribute to the behaviour of OS_ObjectIdGetById and thus to any enclosing for-loop analysis.

- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; converts IDs to indices and may access or modify shared/global structures or contain loops — needed to check loop counters, side effects, and use of objects modified in loop bodies.

- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; token conversion may have loops or modify objects used as loop counters/control flags; must be reviewed.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Callee of OS_ObjectIdGetById; included because its behaviour could affect objects used in loop control and may contain loops itself.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl; translates token → index and may access/modify global data or contain loops that affect MISRA analysis.

- OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime: Callee of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl; timing/compare utilities often include loops or side-effecting operations — must be inspected for for-loop correctness and side effects.

- OS_object_token_t: Type of local variable token passed to callees. Its layout/semantics determine whether fields may be used as loop counters or be modified in called functions.

- osal_id_t: Type of sem_id parameter. Needed to check whether this identifier (or derived objects) could be used as loop counters/control flags in the call chain.

- int32, uint32: Used in the target signature and return/parameter passing; knowing signedness/width may be relevant when checking loop counter modifications and for-loop clause expressions.

- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_SUCCESS: Constants/macros used in the call to OS_ObjectIdGetById. Their definitions may affect the evaluated expressions in the call and can influence control flow (e.g. conditional paths that contain for-loops) — include so the analyser can determine which code paths are taken and whether any for-loops on those paths are well-formed.

Note: The above list covers the target function’s direct callees and the callees they invoke (per the provided static call graph) plus the relevant types/constants used in the target. To fully verify MISRA for-loop requirements you must inspect the implementations of these functions (and any global objects they reference) to find any for statements and confirm their three clauses and any cross-function side effects. If any of these functions reference additional globals or helper functions that contain for-loops, those symbols must also be added for a complete analysis.
